At that time the World-Honored One told the maiden of pure faith:
If bodhisattvas can accomplish eight powers, they will be steadfast, courageous, and tireless in the cycle of birth and death.
What are the eight?

First, the power of aspiration, due to being without deceit or deception; second, the power of resolve, due to being free from all evil; third, the power of practice, due to always cultivating goodness; fourth, the power of pure faith, due to deeply believing in the retribution of karma; fifth, the power of the bodhi mind, due to not seeking the Lesser Vehicle; sixth, the power of great kindness, due to not harming sentient beings; seventh, the power of great compassion, due to being able to endure all evil; eighth, the power of good friends, due to being constantly alerted.
Maiden!

Furthermore, young woman!
Because bodhisattvas accomplish eight kinds of dharmas, they are free from hatred and love.
What are the eight?

First, kindness; second, compassion; third, always practicing benefiting; fourth, not being tainted by worldly dharmas; fifth, not being attached to one's own body; sixth, always cultivating a concentrated mind; seventh, abandoning one's body and life; eighth, observing afflictions.
Cultivating these eight dharmas can free one from hatred and love.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Firmly donning the armor of kindness, having compassion for all,
Abiding in an impartial mind, one will not give rise to hatred and love.
The wise practice benefiting, always bestowing peace and happiness upon others,
Obtaining benefit, they do not become arrogant, and do not give rise to resentment towards humiliation,
Not being moved by the eight winds, one will not give rise to hatred and love.
Towards oneself and others, not giving rise to the notion of hatred and love,
Abandon all thoughts, and do not be attached to objects.
Always observe one's own body, and do not be stingy with one's body and life.
The wise are unmoved by suffering and joy, like empty space.
Well observe afflictions, and be free from both self and what belongs to self.
Uphold practice that is always like the earth, and then do not give rise to aversion or attachment.
Furthermore, young woman!
Because bodhisattvas accomplish eight kinds of dharmas, they are not weary in the cycle of birth and death.
What are the eight?

First, because their wholesome roots are vast; second, because they always observe sentient beings; third, because they always get to see buddhas and make offerings to them; fourth, because they get to see immeasurable buddha-lands; fifth, because they always seek the wisdom of the buddhas; sixth, because they understand that birth and death are like a dream; seventh, because they are not timid about the supreme Dharma; eighth, because they observe the past and future as being like reality.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
If those who practice the Way cultivate goodness without blemish or taint,
Like the pure moon in the sky, liberating suffering sentient beings,
Gathering all merits, therefore, they are not weary of birth and death.
Observing the nature of sentient beings, they firmly practice diligence,

For immeasurable and boundless eons, expounding inconceivable Dharma,
